elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide(III) salts with sodium 2,4,6-trisulphonate, Na3L(H2O)3, (1) (L = 2,4,6-trisulfo-C6H2-OH) and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) led to seven new lanthanide(III) sulfonate hybrids, namely, La(L)(phen)(H2O)3·phen·3H2O (2), Ln2(L)2(phen)2(H2O)5·2phen·8.5H2O (Ln = Pr, 3; Nd, 4), Ln2(L)2(phen)2(H2O)4·2phen·8H2O (Ln = Eu, 5; Gd, 6; Tb, 7), and Nd(L)(phen)(H2O)·phen·H2O (8). 1 features a three-dimensional (3D) network in which the sodium(I) ions are interconnected by chelating and bridging trisulphonate ligands. 2−7 contain [Ln2(L)2(phen)2] dinuclear clusters which are further assembled into 3D supramolecular networks via very weak hydrogen bonds and aromatic packing interactions. 8 features a one-dimensional chain in which two neighboring Nd2O2 dinulear cluster units are further bridged by a pair of sulfonate ligands. 2, 3, 6, and 7 display a broad and strong ligand-centered luminescent emission band in the blue-light region, whereas 4, 5, and 8 exhibit very strong emission bands characteristic of the corresponding lanthanide(III) ions. Magnetic measurements indicate that there is antiferromagnetic interactions between magnetic centers in 3−6 and 8 but ferromagnetic interactions in 7.

Magnetic measurements indicate that there is antiferromagnetic interactions between magnetic centers in 3-6 and 8 but ferromagnetic interactions in 7.

elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide(III) salts with sodium 2,4,6-trisulphonate, Na3L(H2O)3, (1) and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) led to seven new lanthanide(III) sulfonate hybrids (2−8). They display either dinuclear lanthanide(III) trisulfonate clusters or a one-dimensional lanthanide(III) trisulfonate chain, containing additional free phen and lattice water molecules as guest molecules.

They display either dinuclear lanthanide(III) trisulfonate clusters or a one-dimensional lanthanide(III) trisulfonate chain, containing additional free phen and lattice water molecules as guest molecules.

elements.content: There has been significant interest in the design and synthesis of inorganic−organic hybrids owing to their potential application in catalysis, chemical separation, and storage. Among them, metal phosphonates are a class of important compounds. Many metal phosphonates display a layered structure in which the metal centers are bridged by the phosphonate groups, although a variety of one-dimensional (1D) chains and porous three-dimensional (3D) networks have also been reported. The sulfonate group, R-SO3, a structural analogue of phosphonate R-PO3, can also be utilized to build inorganic−organic layered or 3D open framework structures. A series of transition metal or lanthanide phosphonate-sulfonates have also been reported by our group as well as Stock’s group. The sulfonate group is considered to be a weak ligand which is often evidenced by its inability to replace solvent molecules from the coordination spheres of many metal ions, and in many cases they are only involved in hydrogen bonding. In order to improve the coordinated of sulfonate ligands, additional functional groups such as carboxylate, hydroxyl, and amine groups have been attached. Furthermore, a variety of coligands such as phen, bipy, and pyrazine are used in the preparation of metal sulfonates with structures ranging from 0D clusters, 1D chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers to 3D porous frameworks. Most sulfonic ligands used are monosulfonic acids, disulfonic acids, and sulfonated-calixarenes, and reports on ligands containing three sulfonate groups or more (excluding sulfonated calixarences) are scarce. Such ligands are important since they can be used to build various 3D porous frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been significant interest in the design and synthesis of inorganic-organic hybrids owing to their potential application in catalysis, chemical separation, and storage. Among them, metal phosphonates are a class of important compounds. Many metal phosphonates display a layered structure in which the metal centers are bridged by the phosphonate groups, although a variety of one-dimensional (1D) chains and porous three-dimensional (3D) networks have also been reported. The sulfonate group, R-SO3, a structural analogue of phosphonate R-PO3, can also be utilized to build inorganic-organic layered or 3D open framework structures. A series of transition metal or lanthanide phosphonate-sulfonates have also been reported by our group as well as Stock's group. The sulfonate group is considered to be a weak ligand which is often evidenced by its inability to replace solvent molecules from the coordination spheres of many metal ions, and in many cases they are only involved in hydrogen bonding. In order to improve the coordinated of sulfonate ligands, additional functional groups such as carboxylate, hydroxyl, and amine groups have been attached. Furthermore, a variety of coligands such as phen, bipy, and pyrazine are used in the preparation of metal sulfonates with structures ranging from 0D clusters, 1D chains, two-dimensional (2D) layers to 3D porous frameworks. Most sulfonic ligands used are monosulfonic acids, disulfonic acids, and sulfonated-calixarenes, and reports on ligands containing three sulfonate groups or more (excluding sulfonated calixarences) are scarce. Such ligands are important since they can be used to build various 3D porous frameworks.

elements.content: So far most of studies are focused on sulfonates of alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, and transition metals (mainly silver(I)). Lanthanide(III) compounds may exhibit good luminescent properties which have important applications such as light-emitting diodes, tunable lasers, and optical storage. Reports on lanthanide sulfonates are still relatively limited, a majority of them are lanthanide(III) complexes with sulfonated-calixarenes. A few lanthanide compounds of monosulfonate carboxylate ligands have been reported; the carboxylate group exhibits much stronger coordination ability to the lanthanide ions than sulfonate group. Lanthanide(III) complexes of various disulfonate ligands were also reported, most of which display 2D layered or 3D network structures. The barium(II) lanthanide(III) mixed metal complexes with 4,4′-disulfo-2,2′-bipyridine-N,N′-dixoide show microporous frameworks with a high DR surface area of 718 m2/g and an average pore size of 6.4 Å. It is interesting to note that 2,6-naphthalenedisulfonate and 2,6-anthraquinonedisulfonate anions can be intercalated between layered rare earth hydroxides. It is also reported that rare earth arenedisulfonate can be an active and selective catalyst in the oxidation of linalool yielding cyclic hydroxy ethers. To the best of our knowledge, there are no reports on lanthanide(III) metal open frameworks based on trisulfonate ligands. During the sulfonation of the phenylarsonic acid (C6H5-AsO3H2), a novel trisulfonate ligand (H3L = 2,4,6-trisulfo-C6H2-OH) was obtained accidently (Scheme ), and later its sodium(I) salt, Na3L(H2O)3 (L = 2,4,6-trisulfo-C6H2-OH) (1) was synthesized according to modified procedures in the literature. It displays a novel 3D network structure. It contains three sulfonate groups in triangular fashion in addition to a hydroxyl group, and these functional groups make it possible for the ligand to bind with multimetal centers via chelation and bridging. Hence, it is an ideal ligand to build lanthanide(III) coordination open frameworks. Furthermore, phen was used as the auxiliary ligand, which can function as an antenna to enhance the luminescent properties of the lanthanide(III) complexes in addition to more structural diversities. Guided by this idea, seven novel lanthanide(III) trisulfonates, namely, La(L)(phen)(H2O)3·phen·3H2O (2), Ln2(L)2(phen)2(H2O)5·2phen·8.5H2O (Ln = Pr, 3; Nd, 4), Ln2(L)2(phen)2(H2O)4·2phen·8H2O (Ln = Eu, 5; Gd, 6; Tb, 7), and Nd(L)(phen)(H2O)·phen·H2O (8) were obtained. 2−7 contain [Ln2(L)2(phen)2] dinuclear clusters which are further assembled into 3D supramolecular networks via hydrogen bonds and aromatic π···π interactions. 8 features a 1D chain in which two neighboring Nd2O2 dinulear cluster units are further bridged by a pair of trisulfonate ligands. Herein we report their syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for N, C, and H were performed on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. Elemental analyses for the lanthanide elements were carried out on Jobin Yvon Inductively Coupled Plasma OES spectrometer (ICP) Ultima2. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000−400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under an oxygen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns (Cu-Kα) were collected on a XPERT-MPD θ-2θ diffractometer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMSXL SQUID magnetometer. The raw data were corrected for the susceptibility of the container and the diamagnetic contributions of the sample using Pascal constants. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for N, C, and H were performed on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. Elemental analyses for the lanthanide elements were carried out on Jobin Yvon Inductively Coupled Plasma OES spectrometer (ICP) Ultima2. The FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under an oxygen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns (Cu-Kα) were collected on a XPERT-MPD θ-2θ diffractometer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMSXL SQUID magnetometer. The raw data were corrected for the susceptibility of the container and the diamagnetic contributions of the sample using Pascal constants. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer.

elements.content: 2,4,6-Trisulphonic acid was obtained accidently by the sulfonation of the phenylarsonic acid in our attempt to synthesize a sulfonated phenylarsonic acid. Phenylarsonic acid (6.0 g, 30 mmol) was added to freshly distilled SO3 (19.2 g, 240 mmol) at 0 οC, and then the mixture was heated at 85−90 °C for 24 h. The phenylarsonic acid were converted into 2,4,6-trisulphonic acid. Residual SO3 was converted to BaSO4 via the addition of aqueous HCl and BaCl2 to the reaction mixture in water. The excess BaCl2 was removed by concentration, filtration of the saturated solution, and ion-exchange of the residual barium ions on a Dowex 50W-X8 H+ form resin. The eluate was finally concentrated and dried to yield the final product. But yield of the final product is very low (<10%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1 

2,4,6-Trisulphonic acid was obtained accidently by the sulfonation of the phenylarsonic acid in our attempt to synthesize a sulfonated phenylarsonic acid. Phenylarsonic acid (6.0 g, 30 mmol) was added to freshly distilled SO3 (19.2 g, 240 mmol) at 0 οC, and then the mixture was heated at 85-90 °C for 24 h. The phenylarsonic acid were converted into 2,4,6-trisulphonic acid. Residual SO3 was converted to BaSO4 via the addition of aqueous HCl and BaCl2 to the reaction mixture in water. The excess BaCl2 was removed by concentration, filtration of the saturated solution, and ion-exchange of the residual barium ions on a Dowex 50W-X8 H+ form resin. The eluate was finally concentrated and dried to yield the final product. But yield of the final product is very low (<10%).

elements.content: Then it was synthesized according to the slightly modified procedures described in the literature. Sulphuric acid (104.7%) (100 mL) was added to 4-t-butylphenol (7.51 g, 50 mmol) to form a homogeneous solution which was subsequently heated at 35−40 °C for 23 days. The longer the reaction time, the higher the yield of 2,4,6-trisulphonic acid. Residual H2SO4 was converted to BaSO4 via the addition of Ba(OH)2. Hydrochloric acid was added to the filtrate until acid to litmus. The eluate was finally concentrated and dried to yield the final product. The final product by this method is also a mixture.

elements.content: Then the mixture was allowed to react with NaOH at 150 °C for 4 days to convert the trisulfonic acid into its sodium salt. The resultant solution was filtered and the filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly at the room temperature. Salmon pink crystals were collected in a ca. 78% yield after a few weeks. Its purity was also confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) (see ). Anal. Calcd for C6H9Na3O13S3 (M r = 454.28): Na, 15.18; C, 15.86; H, 2.00%. Found: Na, 15.16; C, 15.45; H, 2.11%. elements.content: Single crystals of 2−5 and 8 were performed with a Saturn 70 CCK diffractometer, data collection for 1 and 7 with a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer. All diffractometers were equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data for all compounds were collected by the narrow frame method at 293 K. The data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by a multiscan method. All the structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms excluding those associated with aqua ligands and lattice water molecules were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined with isotropical thermal parameters. The full data collection for 6 was not performed due to its isostructure with 5 and 7 based on their cell parameters. The sulfonate oxygen atoms, O(5), O(6), and O(7) bonding to S(2), and O(12), O(13), and O(14) associated with S(4) in 2 are disordered and each displays two symmetrical related orientations; hence their occupancy factors were reduced to 50%. The occupancy factor for O(14W) in 3 and 4 was reduced to 50% due to its very high thermal parameters, so are O(12W) and O(13W) in 5 and 7. The lattice water molecule in 8 is also disordered over two orientations (O(2W) and O(3W)) with an interatomic distance of 1.13(2) Å; hence, the occupancy factors of O(2W) and O(3W) were fixed to be 50%. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for 1−8 are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths are listed in .

Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single crystals of 2-5 and 8 were performed with a Saturn 70 CCK diffractometer, data collection for 1 and 7 with a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer. All diffractometers were equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data for all compounds were collected by the narrow frame method at 293 K. The data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by a multiscan method. All the structures were solved by the direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms excluding those associated with aqua ligands and lattice water molecules were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined with isotropical thermal parameters. The full data collection for 6 was not performed due to its isostructure with 5 and 7 based on their cell parameters. The sulfonate oxygen atoms, O(5), O(6), and O(7) bonding to S(2), and O(12), O(13), and O(14) associated with S(4) in 2 are disordered and each displays two symmetrical related orientations; hence their occupancy factors were reduced to 50%. The occupancy factor for O(14W) in 3 and 4 was reduced to 50% due to its very high thermal parameters, so are O(12W) and O(13W) in 5 and 7. The lattice water molecule in 8 is also disordered over two orientations (O(2W) and O(3W)) with an interatomic distance of 1.13(2) Å; hence, the occupancy factors of O(2W) and O(3W) were fixed to be 50%. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for 1-8 are summarized in Table . Important bond lengths are listed in .

elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Hydrothermal reactions of Na3L(H2O)3 (1) led to seven novel lanthanide(III) trisulfonates, namely, La(L)(phen)(H2O)3⋅phen⋅3H2O (2), Ln2(L)2(phen)2(H2O)5⋅2phen⋅8.5H2O (Ln = Pr, 3; Nd, 4), Ln2(L)2(phen)2(H2O)4⋅2phen⋅8H2O (Ln = Eu, 5; Gd, 6; Tb, 7), and Nd(L)(phen)(H2O)⋅phen⋅H2O (8). They represent first lanthanide(III) trisulfonates. 2-7 display isolated dinuclear clusters in which the two lanthanide(III) ions are bridged by a pair of L3- anions. 2-8 contain free phen and lattice molecules as guest molecules.

elements.content: Na3L(H2O)3 (1) features a complicated 3D network. There is three unique sodium(I) ions in its asymmetric unit (Figure ). Na(1) is eight-coordinated by seven sulfonate oxygen atoms from four L3− anions and an aqua ligand. Na(2) is seven-coordinated by five sulfonate oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl groups from four L3− anions. Na(3) is octahedrally coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms from two L3− anions and four aqua ligands. The Na−O distances are in the range of 2.322(4)−3.002(4) Å, which are comparable to those reported in other sodium(I) compounds.

Na(1) is eight-coordinated by seven sulfonate oxygen atoms from four L3- anions and an aqua ligand. Na(2) is seven-coordinated by five sulfonate oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl groups from four L3- anions. Na(3) is octahedrally coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms from two L3- anions and four aqua ligands. The Na-O distances are in the range of 2.322(4)-3.002(4) Å, which are comparable to those reported in other sodium(I) compounds.

elements.content: There is one unique L3− ligand in 1. It connects with 10 Na(I) centers by using nine sulfonate oxygen atoms and one hydroxyl group. S(1)O3 adopts a η5 μ4 coordination mode, forming one Na−O−S−O chelation ring and bridging three other sodium(I) ions. The S(2)O3 group adopts a η4 μ3 coordination mode, forming one Na−O−S−O chelation ring and bridging two other sodium(I) ions. S(3)O3 group adopts a η5 μ3 coordination mode, forming two Na−O−S−O chelation rings and bridging the third sodium(I) ion. The hydroxyl group is bidentate bridging (Scheme a). Two of the three aqua ligands (O(1W), O(2W)) are bidentate, whereas the third one (O(3W)) is monodentate.

elements.content: 2 contains two coordination L3− anions lying on a mirror plane, one lanthanum(III) ion, one coordination phen ligand, three aqua ligands as well as one noncoordination phen molecule and three lattice water molecules as guest molecules in its asymmetric unit. The La(III) ion is nine-coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl groups from two L3− anions, one bidentate chelating phen ligand and three aqua ligands. The La−O (2.467(3)−2.666(4) Å) and La−N (2.676(4)−2.709(4) Å) bond distances are comparable to those reported in other lanthanum(III) sulfonates reports.

elements.content: Two unique L3− ligands adopt the same coordination modes (η4 μ2), each forming two La−O−C−C−S−O six-member chelation rings by using two sulfonate oxygen atoms from two sulfonate groups and the hydroxyl group; the third disordered sulfonate group remains noncoordinated (Scheme b). A pair of La(III) ions are bridged by a pair of sulfonate oxygen atoms and hydroxyl groups of two L3− anions into a [La2(L)2(phen)2] dinuclear cluster unit with a La2O2 four-member ring (Figure a). The La···La separation within the [La2(L)2(phen)2] cluster is 4.305(1) Å.

elements.content: 3 and 4 are isostructural and so are 5−7. They contain similar dinuclear cluster units as in 2 (Figure b,c). The only difference is the numbers of the aqua ligands in the cluster and lattice water molecules. The asymmetric units of 3−4 each contains two lanthanide(III) ions, two phen coligands and two phen guest molecules, five aqua ligands and eight and a half lattice water molecules. One of the Ln(III) ions is nine-coordinated as in 2, whereas the other one is eight-coordinated with only two aqua ligands. The asymmetric units of 5−7 each contains two Ln(III) ions, two phen as coligands and two phen guest molecules, four aqua ligands and eight lattice water molecules. Both lanthanide(III) ions are eight-coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms and two hydroxyl groups from two L3− anions, one bidentate chelating phen ligand and two aqua ligands. The L3− anions in 3−7 adopt the same coordination mode as in 2. The Ln···Ln separations within the [Ln2(L)2(phen)2] dinuclear cluster units are 4.0959(6), 4.0874(6), 3.9740(7), and 3.9432(9) Å, respectively, for 3−5 and 7. The cluster unit in 2 contains one and two more aqua ligands than those in 3−4, and 5−7, respectively, which is due to the so-called “lanthanide contraction”. The “lanthanide contraction” is also reflected by the slight decreasing of Ln−O distances and cell dimensions from 2 to 7 (Tables and ).

elements.content: There is one unique H3L ligand in 8. Its coordinated mode is different from those in 1−7 (Scheme c). It acts as a pentadentate metal connector, forming two Nd−O−S−C−C−O six-member chelating rings by using two sulfonate groups and its hydroxyl group, and also bridging to the third Nd(III) ion by using one oxygen atom of the third sulfonate group. Similar to those in 2−7, a pair of Nd(III) ions in 8 is bridged by a pair of L3− anions into such a dinuclear cluster unit with Nd···Nd separation (4.0422(5) Å). Such dinuclear cluster units are further interconnected via the coordination of the third sulfonate groups of the trisulfonate ligands into a 1D chain along the a-axis (Figure a). The shortest interculster Nd···Nd separation is 10.100(1) Å, being much larger than that of a Nd−O−Nd bridge. The guest molecules (phen and lattice water) are located at the interchain space and involved in aromatic packing interaction, which further stabilize the structure of 8 (Figure b, ).

elements.content: The solid-state luminescent properties of 1−8 were investigated at room temperature (Figure ). Under excitation of 350 nm, 1 exhibits a broad and strong blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 444 nm (Figure a), which corresponds to a ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence. Upon the replacement of sodium(I) ion by the lanthanide(III) ions, 5 exhibits three very strong characteristic emission bands for the europium(III) ion in the visible region under excitation at 360 nm (Figure e). These emission bands are 592 (5D0 → 7F1), 613 (5D0 →7F2), and 702 nm (5D0 → 7F4). The Eu (5D0) lifetime of 5 for λex,em = 360, 613 nm is 0.18 s. Under excitation at 357 nm, 4 and 8 display the characteristic emission bands for the neodymium(III) ion: a weak emission band at 952 nm for 4 or 977 nm for 8 (4F3/2 → 4I9/2), strong emission band at 1063 nm for 4 or 1057 nm for 8 (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), and a very weak band at 1333 nm for 4 or 1329 nm for 8 (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near IR region (Figure d,h). The Nd (4F3/2) lifetime for 4 were measured to be 1.01 ns. The luminescent lifetime of 8 is too short to be measured due to the limitation of the instruments. It is noted that the luminescent intensities for emission bands of 8 are much stronger than the corresponding ones of 4, and this is probably due to the fewer coordination and lattice water molecules in 8 than in 4; such high-frequency vibrating water molecules may effectively quench the luminescence states. The emission spectra of 3 and 7 did not show their characteristic emission bands for Pr3+ or Tb3+ ion, which is probably due to the mismatch of the energy levels between the triplet state of the sulfonate ligand and the excited state of the lanthanide(III) ions to produce an effective energy transfer, the so-called “Antenna effect”. They only exhibit a broad and strong ligand-centered blue fluorescent emission bands at λmax = 457 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 3 (Figure c) and λmax = 485 nm (λex = 380 nm) for 7 (Figure g). 2 and 6 also exhibit a broad and strong ligand-centered blue fluorescent emission bands at λmax = 446 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 2 (Figure b) and λmax = 485 nm (λex = 380 nm) for 6 (Figure f). The metal-centered (MC) electronic levels are well above the ligand-centered electronic levels of organic ligands, and typically, the Gd3+ ions are known to be located at 31000 cm−1. Therefore, ligand-to-metal energy transfer and the consequent MC luminescence cannot be observed for Gd(III) compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The solid-state luminescent properties of 1-8 were investigated at room temperature (Figure ). Under excitation of 350 nm, 1 exhibits a broad and strong blue fluorescent emission band at λmax = 444 nm (Figure a), which corresponds to a ligand-centered (LC) fluorescence. Upon the replacement of sodium(I) ion by the lanthanide(III) ions, 5 exhibits three very strong characteristic emission bands for the europium(III) ion in the visible region under excitation at 360 nm (Figure e). These emission bands are 592 (5D0 → 7F1), 613 (5D0 →7F2), and 702 nm (5D0 → 7F4). The Eu (5D0) lifetime of 5 for λex,em = 360, 613 nm is 0.18 s. Under excitation at 357 nm, 4 and 8 display the characteristic emission bands for the neodymium(III) ion: a weak emission band at 952 nm for 4 or 977 nm for 8 (4F3/2 → 4I9/2), strong emission band at 1063 nm for 4 or 1057 nm for 8 (4F3/2 → 4I11/2), and a very weak band at 1333 nm for 4 or 1329 nm for 8 (4F3/2 → 4I13/2) in the near IR region (Figure d,h). The Nd (4F3/2) lifetime for 4 were measured to be 1.01 ns. The luminescent lifetime of 8 is too short to be measured due to the limitation of the instruments. It is noted that the luminescent intensities for emission bands of 8 are much stronger than the corresponding ones of 4, and this is probably due to the fewer coordination and lattice water molecules in 8 than in 4; such high-frequency vibrating water molecules may effectively quench the luminescence states. The emission spectra of 3 and 7 did not show their characteristic emission bands for Pr3+ or Tb3+ ion, which is probably due to the mismatch of the energy levels between the triplet state of the sulfonate ligand and the excited state of the lanthanide(III) ions to produce an effective energy transfer, the so-called "Antenna effect". They only exhibit a broad and strong ligand-centered blue fluorescent emission bands at λmax = 457 nm (λex = 390 nm) for 3 (Figure c) and λmax = 485 nm (λex = 380 nm) for 7 (Figure g). 2 and 6 also exhibit a broad and strong ligand-centered blue fluorescent emission bands at λmax = 446 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 2 (Figure b) and λmax = 485 nm (λex = 380 nm) for 6 (Figure f). The metal-centered (MC) electronic levels are well above the ligand-centered electronic levels of organic ligands, and typically, the Gd3+ ions are known to be located at 31000 cm-1. Therefore, ligand-to-metal energy transfer and the consequent MC luminescence cannot be observed for Gd(III) compounds.

elements.content: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 3−8 were measured in the range 300−2 K (Figure ). 3−6 and 8 display similar magnetic properties, whereas 7 exhibits a different magnetic behavior, although their structures are quite similar (dinuclear clusters with different numbers of aqua ligands and lattice waters).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Property Measurements

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 3-8 were measured in the range 300-2 K (Figure ). 3-6 and 8 display similar magnetic properties, whereas 7 exhibits a different magnetic behavior, although their structures are quite similar (dinuclear clusters with different numbers of aqua ligands and lattice waters).

elements.content: (a−f) Temperature dependence of the χm T and χm −1 for 3−8 at 1000 Oe. The inset plot (e) is the field-dependent magnetization of 7 at 2 K. For 3, 4, 6−8, the solid red lines represent the fittings of χm −1 vs T according to the Curie−Weiss law, whereas the solid red line for 5 (c) denotes the fitting of χm T vs T (λ = 492.9 cm−1 and θ = 1.4 K) on the basis of the equations deduced from the Eu(III) ion in the monomeric system with the free-ion approximation.
elements.clean_text: 8  (a-f) Temperature dependence of the χm T and χm -1 for 3-8 at 1000 Oe. The inset plot (e) is the field-dependent magnetization of 7 at 2 K. For 3, 4, 6-8, the solid red lines represent the fittings of χm -1 vs T according to the Curie-Weiss law, whereas the solid red line for 5 (c) denotes the fitting of χm T vs T (λ = 492.9 cm-1 and θ = 1.4 K) on the basis of the equations deduced from the Eu(III) ion in the monomeric system with the free-ion approximation.

elements.content: For 6, the χm T value decreased continuously upon cooling from the r.t. value of 17.36 cm3·K·mol−1 (expected value 15.86 cm3·K·mol−1), which may be attributed to a combined effect of temperature-independent paramagnetism and antiferromagnetic exchange interaction between two metal centers of the dinuclear unit. The plot of χm −1 vs T over the whole temperature range obeys the Curie−Weiss law with C = 17.21 cm3·K·mol−1 and θ = −17.24 K. For dinuclear gadolinium(III) complexes (Ŝ A = Ŝ B = 7/2), the theoretical expression of the magnetic susceptibility based on Ĥ = −JŜ A·Ŝ B is χ m = 2 N g 2 β 2 k B T × e x + 5e 3 x + 14 e 6 x + 30 e 10 x + 55 e 15 x + 91 e 21 x + 140 e 28 x 1 + 3 e x + 5 e 3 x + 7 e 6 x + 9 e 1 0 x + 11 e 15 x + 13 e 21 x + 15 e 28 x + N α where x = J/k B T, Nα accounts for the temperature-independent paramagnetism. An isotropic g value of 2.00 was assumed. The simulation of experimental data leads to J = −0.13 cm−1, Nα = 0.009 cm3 mol−1, with R = ∑(χobsd − χcalcd)2/∑χ2 obsd = 6.9 × 10−4.

elements.content: For 3, 4, 5, and 8 compared with 6, it is more difficult to analyze their magnetic properties because of the orbital contribution. At 300 K, χm T of 3, 4, 5, and 8 are 3.83, 4.09, 4.85, and 4.00 cm3·K·mol−1, respectively, which are higher than the expected values of two isolated Ln3+ ions (3.20, 3.28, 3.06, and 3.28 cm3·K·mol−1), owing to the measurement error caused by insufficient sample. On lowering the temperature, χm T decreases slowly to ca. 48, 71, and 71 K for 3, 4, and 8, and then it drops rapidly to reach values (0.13, 1.24, and 1.34 cm3·K·mol−1) at 2 K. Fitting of the data (χm −1 vs T) according to the Curie−Weiss law gave Weiss constants (θ) of −74.7, −38.2, and −65.1 K, respectively, for 3, 4, and 8. The decrease of χm T and the negative value of θ are due primarily to splitting of the ligand field of the Ln(III) ions as a result of strong spin−orbital coupling and is attributed partly to the possibly antiferromagnetic intradimer coupling, whereas the χm T of 5 decreases more rapidly as the temperature is lowered and close to zero at 2 K, which should be mainly attributed to the depopulation of the levels with nonzero J values and a J = 0 ground state of the Eu(III) ion (7F0), being also reflected in the small value of the Weiss-like constant θ (θ = 1.4 K) on the basis of the equations deduced from the Eu(III) ion in the monomeric system with the free-ion approximation (Figure c).

On lowering the temperature, χm T decreases slowly to ca. 48, 71, and 71 K for 3, 4, and 8, and then it drops rapidly to reach values (0.13, 1.24, and 1.34 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1) at 2 K. Fitting of the data (χm -1 vs T) according to the Curie-Weiss law gave Weiss constants (θ) of -74.7, -38.2, and -65.1 K, respectively, for 3, 4, and 8. The decrease of χm T and the negative value of θ are due primarily to splitting of the ligand field of the Ln(III) ions as a result of strong spin-orbital coupling and is attributed partly to the possibly antiferromagnetic intradimer coupling, whereas the χm T of 5 decreases more rapidly as the temperature is lowered and close to zero at 2 K, which should be mainly attributed to the depopulation of the levels with nonzero J values and a J = 0 ground state of the Eu(III) ion (7F0), being also reflected in the small value of the Weiss-like constant θ (θ = 1.4 K) on the basis of the equations deduced from the Eu(III) ion in the monomeric system with the free-ion approximation (Figure c).

elements.content: 7 exhibits a magnetic behavior different from those of 3−6 and 8. The observed value of χm T per [Tb2] binuclear unit is 24.71 cm3·K·mol−1 at room temperature, which is slightly larger than the value expected (23.63 cm3·K·mol−1) for the free-ion ground state (7F6) of Tb(III) with six localized unpaired f-electrons. Upon cooling, the values of χm T remain nearly unchanged down to ca. 110 K and then gradually increase up to a maximum of 27.63 cm3·K·mol−1 at ca. 26 K, and subsequently goes down sharply to 15.71 cm3·K·mol−1 at 2 K. The plot of χm −1 vs T over the temperature range 30−300 K obeys the Curie−Weiss law [χm = C/(T − θ)] with C = 23.8 cm3·K·mol−1 and θ = 2.08 K, indicating that there is ferromagnetic coupling between the Tb3+ ions, and the coupling interaction just can completely compensate for the depopulation of the Stark levels.

elements.content: To get more in-depth insights on the magnetic properties of [Tb2] binuclear cluster, the field dependence of the magnetization was performed at 2 K (Figure e). In fact, one observed a rapid increase of the magnetization up to a saturation plateau with increasing field, providing more evidence of the dominant intracluster ferromagnetic coupling. No hysteresis loop was observed, suggesting that the magnetic phase critical temperature is probably lower than 2 K. On the basis of AC magnetic measurements (), it is found that the in-phase magnetization increases with decreasing temperature, but no peak was observed, and the magnetization of out-phase keeps constant within the whole temperature range. This also supports that the magnetic phase critical temperature of 7 is probably lower than 2 K, which is further verified by ZFC-FC measurements ().

elements.content: TGA curves of 1−8 display a small instability due to the presence of a large number of lattice water molecules in these compounds. TGA curves of 1 exhibit two main steps of weight losses (). The first step started at 139 °C and was completed at 317 °C, which corresponds to the release of three aqua ligands. The observed weight loss of 11.3% is very close to the calculated value (11.9%). The second step covering a temperature range of 369−671 °C corresponds to the combustion of the trisulfonate ligands. The final product is assumed to be Na2SO4. The total observed weight loss at 671 °C of 54.9% is close to the calculated value (53.1%). 2 also exhibits two main steps of weight losses (). The first step before 285 °C corresponds to the release of three lattice water molecules and three aqua ligands; the weight loss of 10% is close to the calculated value of 10.9%. The second step (285−770 °C) corresponds to the combustion of free and coordination phen ligands as well as the trisulfonate ligand. The total weight loss at 1100 °C is 76.4%, which is significantly larger than the expected value of 71.3% if we assume the residual is La2(SO4)3; hence, lanthanun(III) oxides should be also formed by decomposition of La2(SO4)3. TGA curves of 3 and 4 are similar, so are those of 5−7. Each of them displays two main steps of the weight losses: the first one is associated with the release of lattice water and aqua ligands, whereas the second one corresponds to the combustion of free and coordination phen ligands as well as the trisulfonate ligands. The final product is assumed to be mainly Ln2(SO4)3 for 3−7. The total observed weight loss and the calculated values are 70.6% and 70.1% at 683 °C for 3, 71.4% and 69.9% for 4 at 716 °C, 68.4% and 68.9% at 745 °C for 5, 68.5% and 68.52% for 6 at 745 °C, and 68.6% and 68.4% for 7 at 749 °C. 8 shows two main steps of weight losses which are overlapped. The thermal decomposing process is expected to be similar to those of 2−7 despite its different structure and the numbers of lattice molecules and aqua liagnds. The total weight loss at 800 °C is 68.4%, which is slightly higher than the expected value of 67.0% if we assume the residual is mainly Nd2(SO4)3.

The first step started at 139 °C and was completed at 317 °C, which corresponds to the release of three aqua ligands. The observed weight loss of 11.3% is very close to the calculated value (11.9%). The second step covering a temperature range of 369-671 °C corresponds to the combustion of the trisulfonate ligands. The final product is assumed to be Na2SO4. The total observed weight loss at 671 °C of 54.9% is close to the calculated value (53.1%). 2 also exhibits two main steps of weight losses (). The first step before 285 °C corresponds to the release of three lattice water molecules and three aqua ligands; the weight loss of 10% is close to the calculated value of 10.9%. The second step (285-770 °C) corresponds to the combustion of free and coordination phen ligands as well as the trisulfonate ligand. The total weight loss at 1100 °C is 76.4%, which is significantly larger than the expected value of 71.3% if we assume the residual is La2(SO4)3; hence, lanthanun(III) oxides should be also formed by decomposition of La2(SO4)3. TGA curves of 3 and 4 are similar, so are those of 5-7. Each of them displays two main steps of the weight losses: the first one is associated with the release of lattice water and aqua ligands, whereas the second one corresponds to the combustion of free and coordination phen ligands as well as the trisulfonate ligands. The final product is assumed to be mainly Ln2(SO4)3 for 3-7. The total observed weight loss and the calculated values are 70.6% and 70.1% at 683 °C for 3, 71.4% and 69.9% for 4 at 716 °C, 68.4% and 68.9% at 745 °C for 5, 68.5% and 68.52% for 6 at 745 °C, and 68.6% and 68.4% for 7 at 749 °C. 8 shows two main steps of weight losses which are overlapped. elements.content: In summary, the syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of a sodium(I) and lanthanide(III) trisulfonates have been reported. The sodium(I) compound is three-dimensional. whereas the lanthanide compounds are zero- or one-dimensional due to the coordination of the phen coligands. Furthermore, guest molecules such as free phen and lattice water molecules are present in the lanthanide(III) complexes. Hydrogen bonding as well as aromatic packing interaction in these lanthanide(III) complexes further stabilize these supramolecular assemblies. This trisulfonate ligand can adopt different coordination modes according to the nature and size of the cations. It is believed that a variety of other heteronuclear or homonuclear luminescent lanthanide clusters can be prepared by using a similar synthetic route and our future research efforts will be devoted to these possibilities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the syntheses, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of a sodium(I) and lanthanide(III) trisulfonates have been reported. The sodium(I) compound is three-dimensional. whereas the lanthanide compounds are zero- or one-dimensional due to the coordination of the phen coligands. Furthermore, guest molecules such as free phen and lattice water molecules are present in the lanthanide(III) complexes. Hydrogen bonding as well as aromatic packing interaction in these lanthanide(III) complexes further stabilize these supramolecular assemblies. This trisulfonate ligand can adopt different coordination modes according to the nature and size of the cations. It is believed that a variety of other heteronuclear or homonuclear luminescent lanthanide clusters can be prepared by using a similar synthetic route and our future research efforts will be devoted to these possibilities.

cln_elements.content:
2,4,6-Trisulphonic acid was obtained accidently by the sulfonation of the phenylarsonic acid in our attempt to synthesize a sulfonated phenylarsonic acid. Phenylarsonic acid (6.0 g, 30 mmol) was added to freshly distilled SO3 (19.2 g, 240 mmol) at 0 οC, and then the mixture was heated at 85−90 °C for 24 h. The phenylarsonic acid were converted into 2,4,6-trisulphonic acid. Residual SO3 was converted to BaSO4 via the addition of aqueous HCl and BaCl2 to the reaction mixture in water. The excess BaCl2 was removed by concentration, filtration of the saturated solution, and ion-exchange of the residual barium ions on a Dowex 50W-X8 H+ form resin. The eluate was finally concentrated and dried to yield the final product. But yield of the final product is very low (<10%).

Then it was synthesized according to the slightly modified procedures described in the literature. Sulphuric acid (104.7%) (100 mL) was added to 4-t-butylphenol (7.51 g, 50 mmol) to form a homogeneous solution which was subsequently heated at 35−40 °C for 23 days. The longer the reaction time, the higher the yield of 2,4,6-trisulphonic acid. Residual H2SO4 was converted to BaSO4 via the addition of Ba(OH)2. Hydrochloric acid was added to the filtrate until acid to litmus. The eluate was finally concentrated and dried to yield the final product. The final product by this method is also a mixture.

Then the mixture was allowed to react with NaOH at 150 °C for 4 days to convert the trisulfonic acid into its sodium salt. The resultant solution was filtered and the filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly at the room temperature. Salmon pink crystals were collected in a ca. 78% yield after a few weeks. Its purity was also confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) (see ). Anal. Calcd for C6H9Na3O13S3 (M r = 454.28): Na, 15.18; C, 15.86; H, 2.00%. Found: Na, 15.16; C, 15.45; H, 2.11%. IR data (KBr, cm−1): 3288 (w), 3089 (w), 2346 (w), 1692 (w), 1596 (m), 1441 (w), 1199 (vs), 1108 (m), 1046 (vs), 902 (w), 811 (w), 749 (m), 607 (m), 546 (m).

Syntheses of <bold>2</bold>−<bold>8</bold>

They were synthesized by a similar method. A mixture of LnCl3·6H2O (Ln = La, Pr, Nd, Eu, Gd, Tb) (0.11 g, 0.3 mmol), Na3L(H2O)3 (0.14 g, 0.3 mmol), phen (0.06 g, 0.3 mmol) in 10 mL of deionized water, was put into a Parr Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL), and heated at 150 °C for 4 days. The initial and final pH values of solution are 3.5 and 3.0, respectively. Buff-prism crystals of 2 and colorless brick-shaped crystals for 8 were directly collected in a ca. yield of 53% (0.07 g) and 72% (0.09 g), respectively, based on phen. Crystals of 3−7 were obtained by the slow evaporation of the resultant reaction solution at the room temperature for two weeks. The yields are ca. 60% (0.08 g), 65% (0.09 g), 25% (0.04 g), 34% (0.05 g), and 70% (0.1 g), respectively, based on phen. Their purities were also confirmed by XRD powder diffraction (see ). Anal. Calcd for 2: La, 14.08; C, 36.52; H, 3.17, N, 5.68%; Found: La, 13.76; C, 36.31; H, 3.12; N, 5.59%. For 3: Pr, 14.77; C, 37.76; H, 3.43; N, 5.87%. Found: Pr, 14.80; C, 37.69; H, 3.38; N, 5.82%. For 4: Nd, 15.06; C, 37.63; H, 3.42; N, 5.85%. Found: Nd, 15.02; C, 37.6; H, 3.35; N, 5.77%. For 5: Eu, 15.97; C, 37.86; H, 3.28; N, 5.89%. Found: Eu, 16.67; C, 37.79; H, 3.21; N, 5.81%. For 6: Gd, 16.43; C, 37.65; H, 3.26; N, 5.85%; Found: Gd, 16.92; C, 37.55, H, 3.21, N, 5.67%. For 7: Tb, 16.58; C, 37.58; H, 3.26; N, 5.84%. Found: Tb, 16.82; C, 37.43; H, 3.20; N, 5.81%. For 8: Nd, 16.54; C, 41.32; H, 2.66; N, 6.43%; Found: Nd, 15.50; C, 41.17; H, 2.61; N, 6.39%. IR data (KBr, cm−1) for 2: 3231 (m), 3065 (m), 2828 (w), 1594 (m), 1543 (m), 1521 (w), 1472 (w), 1429 (s), 1281 (m), 1232 (s), 1176 (vs), 1093 (s), 1036 (vs), 970 (w), 909 (w), 881 (w), 847 (s), 813 (m), 775 (m), 735 (m), 718 (m), 602 (s), 536 (w). The first step before 285 °C corresponds to the release of three lattice water molecules and three aqua ligands; the weight loss of 10% is close to the calculated value of 10.9%. The second step (285−770 °C) corresponds to the combustion of free and coordination phen ligands as well as the trisulfonate ligand. The total weight loss at 1100 °C is 76.4%, which is significantly larger than the expected value of 71.3% if we assume the residual is La2(SO4)3; hence, lanthanun(III) oxides should be also formed by decomposition of La2(SO4)3. TGA curves of 3 and 4 are similar, so are those of 5−7. Each of them displays two main steps of the weight losses: the first one is associated with the release of lattice water and aqua ligands, whereas the second one corresponds to the combustion of free and coordination phen ligands as well as the trisulfonate ligands. The final product is assumed to be mainly Ln2(SO4)3 for 3−7. The total observed weight loss and the calculated values are 70.6% and 70.1% at 683 °C for 3, 71.4% and 69.9% for 4 at 716 °C, 68.4% and 68.9% at 745 °C for 5, 68.5% and 68.52% for 6 at 745 °C, and 68.6% and 68.4% for 7 at 749 °C. 8 shows two main steps of weight losses which are overlapped. The thermal decomposing process is expected to be similar to those of 2−7 despite its different structure and the numbers of lattice molecules and aqua liagnds. The total weight loss at 800 °C is 68.4%, which is slightly higher than the expected value of 67.0% if we assume the residual is mainly Nd2(SO4)3.

metadata.title: A Series of Novel Lanthanide(III) Trisulfonates Based on Dinuclear Clusters
